closure_reason: Case Closed. Closed date : 2018-12-27 12:26:00.667 Case Noted The primary intent of this project was to improve pedestrian safety along & across the Beacon Street corridor. To achieve a corridor that reflects the context of the downtown urban fabric and the goals of the City for a safer street  the BTD enacted a number of improvements to the design of the roadway. This was accomplished through the changes to the traffic signal phasing at intersections  the narrowing of crossings through the removal of a travel lane  improvements to sight-lines & visibility through daylighting  and the introduction of the parking-protected bike lane to encourage non-vehicular transportation choices.     Due to the heavy volumes of vehicles departing downtown in the PM peak who choose to make the right-turn onto Storrow Drive at Berkeley Street  it was required to maintain all existing vehicular lanes on the block on Beacon St between Arlington to Berkeley Sts. The introduction of a continuous bike lane from Arlington St would require the removal of curb-side parking entitlements.    After the Berkeley Street intersection  toward Massachusetts Ave  traffic analyses have shown that volumes are below the engineering threshold for a having the travel third lane. Community input has also lent support for significant reductions in speed on Beacon Street  as it is also a residential corridor. Removal of a travel lane has been shown to be a proven measure at reducing vehicular travel speeds.    Utilizing many non-vehicular modes in your mobility choices is greatly appreciated and further encouraged. Your commitment to remaining alert and observant is essential to maintaining safe conditions for all users across the City.

The proposed improvement plan consists of constructing a neck-down on the NW corner with new pedestrian ramps and installation of a Rectangular Rapid Flash Beacon (RRFB).  The plan is aimed at improving pedestrian safety at this intersection by improving sight lines reducing conflict points  reducing the crossing distance and providing a flashing beacon warning motorists that a pedestrian is in the crosswalk.  There is also a benefit to bicyclists as motorists will have to transition through the intersection and yield to bicycles in the bike lane in order to access the exclusive right turn lane.  These plans are consistent with the Boston Complete Streets and Vision Zero initiatives.    The concept plan was developed during the East Boston Action Plan completed in 2008 and there were several meetings held at the time.  At these meetings  residents in the neighborhood expressed concern about the safety of pedestrians crossing Saratoga St at this intersection.  The plans were presented at a Neighborhood Council meeting held on May 18  2015 at the Orient Heights Yacht Club and  there were over 100 people in attendance a representative from PWD Engineering Division also attend the meeting.  The Council and the Boston Police Department were very much in favor of this plan to improve safety at this intersection.
